Classifying droughts using monthly oceanic indices, global meteorological and vegetation data, location (latitude, longitude), and land cover for the years 1982 to 2018 is a crucial task. Our work proposes extracting features by considering the atmosphere and land moisture and energy budgets to forecast global droughts on a seasonal and annual scale at 1, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 24 months lead times. The Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) helps identify the severity and duration of droughts, enabling classification as meteorological, agricultural, and hydrological.

Climate change increases the likelihood of extreme events such as heatwaves, droughts, excessive rainfall, wildfires, and floods, with severe impacts on food security, supply chains, and the world economy. Droughts pose a significant risk to food security, affecting 700 million people who suffer from malnutrition and hunger, leading to lower immunity, delayed development, and increased risk of chronic diseases. The economic cost of a single drought can be up to 9.6 billion US dollars. Predicting droughts to mitigate their impacts is challenging due to their slow onset and varying dependence on physical and socio-economic factors.

Recent machine learning methods, computational resources, and earth observation datasets can aid global drought forecasting. Water in the Earth system is cycled between its gaseous, liquid, and solid forms, remaining constant on timescales relevant to drought prediction (months-years). A drought occurs when there is a water deficit over a prolonged period at the land (agricultural), in the atmosphere (meteorological), or underground (hydrological) level.

We propose extracting features by considering the relevant atmosphere and land moisture and energy budgets and predicting global droughts by modeling SPI on a seasonal and annual scale and predicting precipitation at 1, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 24 months lead times using our deep learning model. SPI helps identify the severity and duration of droughts to classify them as meteorological, agricultural, and hydrological.

The Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) is a widely used drought index to measure droughts. The World Meteorological Organization recommends using SPI for monitoring and reporting purposes. Several algorithms based on stochastic, probabilistic, and machine learning techniques have been proposed to forecast SPI at multiple regional and temporal scales. Machine learning models such as Artificial Neural Network (ANN), Wavelet ANN, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Convolutional LSTM, integrated ANN, and Transformers have been successful for precipitation and drought forecasting individually.

However, most existing machine-learning drought prediction techniques train separate models for each region, which are not able to learn patterns consistent over different types of heterogeneous regions and are more likely to overfit to regional observational data. A location-agnostic approach may be preferable for drought forecasting, indicating that global drought forecasting is a promising direction.

Our dataset for DeepXD is curated to predict SPI and has a temporal coverage from 1982 to 2018 at a monthly resolution (444 timesteps) and spatial coverage across the globe at a resolution of 0.5 x 0.5 degree. The input variables are processed and resampled to the specified resolution after being collected from the global dataset ERA5 and the oceanic indices from NOAA. The target variable is SPI, computed from precipitation from the global land dataset WFDE5.
